reasoning: The critique targets a specific quantitative “star-count” punchline used to argue that (difference-making) bounded views with separate aggregation are extremely fussy because even a 10^-22 fraction of resources going to bads prevents a mostly-great future. That’s a meaningful support for the paper’s broader “most plausible moral views are fussy” claim, but it is only one route among several (multiplicative fragility arguments, unbounded-linear/resource-efficiency arguments, other bounded-view cases, etc.), so centrality is moderate rather than high. The critique has decent strength against that local argument: the paper’s move from ‘fraction of resources’ to ‘fraction of the disvalue bound’ relies on tacit assumptions about (a) disvalue per unit resource, (b) how the bounded transform saturates for bads, and (c) what counts as “bads” produced by that resource share; changing these can substantially weaken the “tiny bad ruins mostly-great” conclusion. However, the critique somewhat overstates by implying the result largely disappears in “many plausible” specifications; the paper’s conclusion can be reinstated under reasonable symmetric/linear-in-bads per resource assumptions, and the argument was partly illustrative rather than fully derived. Most of what the critique says is true and relevant, and it is clearly presented with little fluff, focusing on a single issue.
title: "The paper relies on undefended scaling assumptions"
